attributes.title: Testing a Novel Belief Undermining Instruction (BUI) on Showup Identification Procedures

q1.value: Mitigating the Suggestiveness of Showup Identification Procedures

q3.value: Recently, it has been recommended via the updated ‘White Paper’ on eyewitness identification procedures that, in order to protect innocent suspects in showup procedures, law enforcement should implement procedural safeguards such as unbiased instructions prior to identifications (Wells et al., 2020). However, very little empirical research has examined safeguards to reduce the suggestiveness of showups; the few studies that have been conducted on this topic (Smith et al., 2018; Eisen et al., 2017) have failed to show a benefit of their instructional safeguard (AOI; additional opportunities instruction)  under ecologically valid conditions. The main objective of the proposed study is to provide an experimental test of whether a novel pre-showup instruction (BUI; belief undermining instruction)—created specifically to minimize the suggestiveness of showups per se—improves showup identification accuracy using a novel, ecologically-valid paradigm. Additionally, the present study will examine whether the beneficial effects of the AOI generalize past laboratory studies through a novel experimental paradigm

q4.value: It is hypothesized that the AOI should fail to improve identification decisions using this new paradigm in which witnesses believe the police believe the person being presented is the culprit (meta-belief). However, because our novel BIU should undermine witnesses’ meta-beliefs, the BUI is predicted to reduce false identification rates among target-absent witnesses.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: This study conforms to a 2 (target status: target-present vs. target-absent) X 2 (additional-opportunities instruction: given vs. not given) X 2 (belief instruction: given vs. not given) between-subjects design. Participants will be randomly assigned to all conditions.

q9.value: Participants will be randomly assigned to all experimental conditions through the randomization tool on Qualtrics.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q11.value: This project will not be using data that already exists.

question.value:
The study will be presented via Qualtrics. Participants will first read a cover story which will inform them that the video they are about to watch is property of the Miami-Dade police department and was captured by a concerned citizen who submitted the video to the Miami-Dade Crime Stoppers website anonymously. They will be told the psychology department is collaborating with the Miami-Dade Police to test a new policy and it is their duty to make an attempt at identifying the perpetrator in accordance with these new policies. This cover story will be included to ensure participants believe they are watching an actual crime. For full cover story and instructions, see attached Appendix A. 
After reading the cover story and instructions, participants will be shown the mock crime video (approximately 40 seconds in length). Immediately after the mock crime, participants will complete the 10-minute filler task. 
Participants will then be randomly assigned to an experimental condition in accordance with our proposed design  (2 (target status: target-present vs. target-absent) X 2 (additional-opportunities instruction: given vs. not given) X 2 (belief instruction: given vs. not given) between-subjects design). Participants will be presented with a set of instructions, according to their assigned condition. To see instructions in their entirety according to condition, see Appendix B. 
After reading instructions, Participants will then be prompted to make their identification decision by answering the multiple-choice question “Is the suspect in the photograph the perpetrator you saw in the original video?” with either “yes” or “no” answer choices. After their identification decision, participants will be asked to report their level of confidence from 0% to 100% (in 10-point increments) and will then be presented with a short follow-up questionnaire including an attention check, a question addressing any suspicions, memory quality and demographic information. To see the follow-up questionnaire, see Appendix C.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 1200 participants.

q14.value: Our sample size was determined based on our proposed analyses, which will be receiver-operator characteristic (ROC) curves, a technique recommended by eyewitness researchers (e.g., Wixted & Mickes, 2012). Past studies that have examined the influence of variables that affect false identifications by roughly the same magnitude as is expected of our manipulated instruction have shown differences in ROC curves using approximately 220-300 participants per constructed ROC curve (Gronlund et al., 2012; Mickes, Flowe, & Wixted, 2012); consequently, a sample size of 300 participants per ROC curve was adopted, for a total of 1200 participants.

q15.value: We will be posting sign-ups via Amazon Mechanical Turk (mTurk), posting 100 spots at a time. We will stop once 1200 surveys have been completed and we've confirmed each participant has passed our attention and  manipulation checks.

question.value: We are manipulated three variables. Target status, with two levels: target-present vs. target-absent. Presence of the additional-opportunities instruction, with two levels: given vs. not given. Presence of the  belief undermining instruction, with two levels: given vs. not given.

Our primary dependent variable will be identification decision. There are four potential outcomes- correctly identify the perpetrator, falsely identify an innocent suspect as the perpetrator, correctly reject a target-absent showup, or incorrectly miss the identification of the actual perpetrator.  Our secondary measured variable, we will measure witnesses confidence in their identification decision. Additionally, we will measure participants experiences as a witness using 11 post- identification questions in the post-identification questionnaire, to see exact questions and response options, see Appendix C.

We will be using receiver-operator characteristic (ROC) curves, a technique recommended by eyewitness researchers (e.g., Wixted & Mickes, 2012) that will be described in more detail in the analysis plan section.

The effectiveness of the AOI and the BI will be determined via analyses of correct/false identification rates, and correct/false showup rejection rates. I will construct receiver-operator characteristic (ROC) curves, a technique recommended by eyewitness researchers (e.g., Wixted & Mickes, 2012) that involves plotting the proportion of correct identifications as a function of the proportion of false identifications at various levels of decision criteria (for which witnesses’ confidence reports serve as a proxy). This analysis produces a family of correct identification/false identification pairs that can be described with a curve; four different curves (corresponding to the four different instruction conditions) will then be compared to one another (by comparing their respective partial areas under the curve) to determine the procedure that produces the optimal discriminability. In addition to ROC analyses, I will also examine the extent to which confidence is related to accuracy among both choosers and nonchoosers. To examine this, I will conduct confidence-accuracy calibration (CAC) analyses, which examines identification decisions among witnesses who identified the suspect. This analysis involves plotting the proportion of accurate decisions at various levels of witness confidence. Following past studies, witness confidence will be binned into low (0-60%), medium (70-80%), and high (90-100%) confidence.

q20.value: At this time, there are no plans to transform data in any way.

q21.value: For our ROC analyses, our inference criteria will be area under the curve (AUC) and partial area under the curve (pAUC). The AUC and pAUC of our manipulated instructions (AOI and BUI respectively) will be compared to each other to determine which procedure is the more diagnostic identification procedure.

q22.value: Several factors will result in data exclusion. First, incomplete surveys will be excluded from data analyses. Additionally, respondents that fail our manipulation checks or attention check questions will be excluded from data analyses.

q23.value: The Qualtrics survey will require forced responses for participants, therefore there should be no missing data from completed survey responses. Incomplete surveys will be excluded from data analyses.

q24.value: At this time, we have no planned exploratory analyses.

q25.value:
Eisen, M. L., Smith, A. M., Olaguez, A. P., & Skerritt-Perta, A. S. (2017). An examination of showups conducted by law enforcement using a field-simulation paradigm. Psychology, Public Policy, and Law, 23(1), 1. 

Gronlund, S. D., Carlson, C. A., Neuschatz, J. S., Goodsell, C. A., Wetmore, S. A., Wooten, A., & Graham, M. (2012). Showups versus lineups: An evaluation using ROC analysis. Journal of Applied Research in Memory and Cognition, 1(4), 221-228.

Mickes, L., Flowe, H. D., & Wixted, J. T. (2012). Receiver operating characteristic analysis of eyewitness memory: Comparing the diagnostic accuracy of simultaneous versus sequential lineups. Journal of Experimental Psychology: Applied, 18(4), 361.

Smith, A. M., Wells, G. L., Lindsay, R. C. L., & Myerson, T. (2018). Eyewitness identification performance on showups improves with an additional-opportunities instruction: Evidence for present–absent criteria discrepancy. Law and human behavior.

Wells, G. L., Kovera, M. B., Douglass, A. B., Brewer, N., Meissner, C. A., & Wixted, J. T. (2020). Policy and procedure recommendations for the collection and preservation of eyewitness identification evidence. Law and Human Behavior, 44(1), 3.

Wixted, J. T., & Mickes, L. (2012). The field of eyewitness memory should abandon probative value and embrace receiver operating characteristic analysis. Perspectives on Psychological Science, 7(3), 275-278.

attributes.title: Modulating motor adaptation to auditory perturbation using non-invasive brain stimulation
attributes.description: This project covers a range of preregistered studies which investigate the use of various non-invasive brain stimulation techniques to modulate speech-motor function.

q1.value: Modulating motor adaption to auditory perturbation using transcranial direct current stimulation

q3.value: Auditory perturbation is known to cause speech disfluencies in typical, healthy speakers. Individuals will often make compensatory adjustments to their motor actions to account for said perturbations. Although research has highlighted that the speed and magnitude of these compensatory adjustments can be modulated through transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS), the neuroanatomical substrates for this adjustment is unclear. The study will target specific “speech-motor” areas with anodal stimulation (the ventral motor cortex/vMC and the inferior parietal lobe/IPL) as well as a “reference” montage targeting the supraorbital areas. The purpose of the study is to 1.) replicate the original modulatory effects of tDCS and 2.) Establish whether this effect is contingent on electrode placement or an effect of stimulation generally.

q4.value:
1.	That speakers will make compensatory motor movements to account for the auditory perturbations to their speech. This is non-directional.

2.	That speakers with electrode montages targeting “speech-motor” areas will show a significantly greater adjustment to the perturbation than speakers with electrode montages targeting the supraorbital regions. This is directional.

3.	That speakers with electrode montages targeting the “speech-motor” areas will show a significantly greater adjustment to the perturbation during the stimulation phase than the sham phase of the experiment. This is directional.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

q7.value: The researchers conducting the experiment will not be blinded to the electrode montage but will be blinded to type of stimulation (real vs. sham)

question.value:
The study is a 3x2 Mixed factorial design.
Factor 1: electrode placement of the anodal and cathodal electrodes. This includes arrangements targeting 1.) the ventral motor cortex, 2.) the inferior parietal lobe and 3.) the supraorbital areas. This is a between-subjects measure.
Factor 2: Type of stimulation. Being either sham or actual stimulation. This is a within-subjects measure.
Counter-balancing: The order of factor two will be counter-balanced to ensure the an even number of participants received sham 1st to those who received actual stimulation 1st.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Sampling: opportunistic sampling through University register.
Population: Typical, healthy speakers in London
Payment: Approx. £10/hour
Eligibility: no prior experience with tDCS, normal hearing and typical fluent speech.

q13.value: From a power analysis, below, the desired sample size will be 100 participants overall. Approximately 33 per group.

q14.value:
Power analysis using *gPower based on a small effect size of the stimulation:

Input:
Effect size f(V) = 0.35
α err prob. = 0.05
Power (1-β err prob) = 0.95
Number of groups = 4
Number of measurements = 3
Correlation among measurements = .5

Output:
Numerator & Denominator. Df’s: 3, 96
Non-centrality parameter λ = 18.375
Critical F = 2.6993926
Total sample size = 100
Actual power = 0.9553189

question.value:
Factor 1. The fundamental frequency of the vowel produced. In order to investigate how the brain accounts for auditory perturbation, part of the experiment will involve shifting fundamental frequency of the participants' speech by a pre-set and then returning to normal feedback environment.

Factor 2. Electrode montage. In order to further investigate neuroanatomical substrates of the aforementioned phenomenon, we will vary the site of anodal stimulation. Being the left ventral motor cortex, the left inferior parietal lobe and the right supraorbital area (see figure attached).

Factor 3: Type of stimulation. In order to investigate whether stimulation does indeed cause a non-trivial effect over placebo, measurements will be taken under sham and actual stimulation. Concretely, under the sham condition participants will receive stimulation for a period of 1 minute at the beginning, ramping up to 100% for the 1st 30 seconds ramping down for the remaining 30 seconds. Under the actual stimulation condition, participants will receive stimulation throughout the experiment (~25mins) ramping up to 100% at the beginning 30 seconds and then ramping down to 0% for the last 30 seconds.

Fundamental frequency of the vowel produced. The speech produced will be recorded by a microphone for offline analysis. The vowel component of the speech will be isolated. The 1st formant of these recordings will then be estimated in both baseline (normal auditory feedback) and experimental (Perturbed auditory feedback) conditions.

Sets of 3 trials will be averages to produces blocks within the experiment. Average difference between normal and perturbed auditory feedback denotes the magnitude of adaptation. Changes in average frequency from one block to the next denotes the rate of adaptation.

A 3x2x2 Repeated measures ANOVA with both within- and between-subjects factors will be modelled on the data. The overall effect of F1 manipulation (Factor 1) would be tested across groups. Factor 2, the site of stimulation, would be tested between-groups. Factor 3, sham vs. active, would be looked at within-groups.

Specific comparisons of rate and magnitude of compensation during the perturbation period between 1.) the active condition and 2.) the sham condition will indicate whether there is a general effect of stimulation.

Specific comparisons of rate and magnitude of compensation between 1.) Supra-orbital vs. inferior parietal lobe & motor cortex and 2.) Motor cortex vs. inferior parietal lobe.

See comparison coding under 'Transformations'.

q20.value: As mentioned, specific comparisons will be made between the sites of stimulation. Using the supra-orbital montage as a reference, a Helmert coding scheme will be employed to look at the effects of MC and IPL stimulation. Helmert was chosen as the stimulation is thought to be orthogonal. A Helmert coding scheme will also be used for the comparison of IPL vs. MC.

q21.value: For the main effect of the ANOVA and the specified pairwise comparisons, we will use a standard p less than .05 criteria. Any further comparisons outside those listed under the statistical model will be adjusted using the Bonferroni adjustment.

q22.value:
If trials within the 1st block fall outside of 2 standard deviations of the baseline it will be excluded. If trials in the perturbed feedback blocks fall outside of 2 standard deviations of the previous 2 trials it will be excluded.

If a trial contains a stutter or a speech dysfluency, it will be excluded.

q23.value: If the voice recording is incomplete, the participant's data will not be used. Nor if there are no data for the normal hearing check.

q24.value: The extent to which tDCS affects motor adaptation in the IPL, MC and supra-orbital regions will guide simulation of the DIVA model to try to simulate and model the effects of stimulation within a neurally explicit account of speech.

attributes.title: Persuasion or Loyalty? The Effects of Elite Communication on the Electoral Sanctioning of Corruption

q1.value: Persuasion or Loyalty? The Effects of Elite Communication on the Electoral Sanctioning of Corruption - A Survey Experiment in Hungary

q3.value: This pre-analysis plan summarizes the experimental design for an original survey experiment conducted in Hungary. The experiment tests the effect of the various elements of elite communication on the electoral sanctioning of corruption. The study builds on the previous findings that partisanship – a strong in-group bias – attenuates the extent to which voters’ sanction co-partisan corruption. Yet these studies rarely reflect on the external effects that provoke partisan biases in corruption sanctioning. Therefore, this study invites an elite communication perspective to the study of the electoral sanctioning of corruption. The question we look at is how co-partisan elites able to provoke partisan identities, and correspondingly how voters respond to co-partisan calls when they face co-partisan corruption. Specifically, we compare the effects of elite persuasions and source cues - two distinct components of elite communication – to answer the question whether voters need persuasion not to sanction co-partisan corruption, or they simply respond to known partisan loyalties. In the first stage, the study will ask the question whether persuasive efforts are necessary and efficient when partisan cues are already available. In the second stage, the study will test the mechanisms by which these communication components work to account for the similarities, or differences in their effects on co-partisan sanctioning.

q4.value:
Main Effect Hypotheses:
Hypothesis 1: Voters, even co-partisans, do sanction when they exposed to information about political corruption.

Hypothesis 2: The extent of this sanctioning is conditional on the accessibility of the partisan affiliation of the politician: Co-partisan cues decrease electoral sanctioning substantially.

Hypothesis 3: In the absence of partisan cues, elite arguments against corruption accusations attenuate electoral sanctioning of corruption, however, its effect is weaker compared to the effect of partisan cues.

Hypothesis 4: When partisan cues are available, elite arguments against corruption accusations do not further decrease electoral sanctioning. The combined effect of cues and arguments is not distinguishable from the cues’ effect alone.

Mechanism Hypotheses:
Mechanism Hypothesis 1: Arguments discredit information acquired about corruption. They lower the perception of corruption.

Mechanism Hypothesis 2: Cues work the same way as arguments, they lower the level of the perception of corruption. Therefore, short-term arguments do not make a difference when paired with cues, because cues contain and condense arguments on the long-term already.

Mechanism Hypothesis 3: In contrast with arguments, cues do not lower the level of corruption perception. Cues rather work through strengthening trade-offs for corruption: They improve and keep high voter ranking of other candidate traits even after voters learn about corruption. Therefore, cues create an explicit exchange situation.

Mechanism Hypothesis 4: Cues elicit both mechanisms: They lower the level of corruption perception and improve and keep high the level of candidate traits in voter rankings. Thereby, the two mechanisms combined create a perception bias and an implicit exchange situation.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

question.value:
The paper studies the elite communication effects on the partisan biases of sanctioning in a survey experimental design, where the manipulation comes in the form of vignettes. 

The between-subjects experiment deploys a fractional factorial design with a 2x3 experimental matrix where the two main experimental blocs differ in terms of whether they reveal the partisanship of the politician in the corruption news or not. In each block, a control group will read a short biography of the featured politician. Then, the second pair of groups are exposed to a piece of corruption news featuring the politician (with or without the cue). The third pair of groups will also read a rebuttal from the politician in extra. 

Therefore the following combination of manipulated variables are observed: 
I. Party Cue(0), Exposure to Corruption (0), Elite Argument (0)
II. Party Cue (0), Exposure to Corruption (1), Elite Argument (0)
II. Party Cue (0), Exposure to Corruption (1), Elite Argument (1) 

I. Party Cue(1), Exposure to Corruption (0), Elite Argument (0)
II. Party Cue (1), Exposure to Corruption (1), Elite Argument (0)
II. Party Cue (1), Exposure to Corruption (1), Elite Argument (1) 

The design will help us to observe the relative effect of the news exposure and arguments on the extent of sanctioning in the cue and the non-cue conditions/blocs, enabling us to study the central comparisons and mechanisms in terms of persuasive effects and partisan cues.

A. No Cue Block:
nc1: The control group respondents read a description of a politician, but do not receive the corruption news featuring the politician. This group intends to serve as the baseline measurement of the featured politician’s approval, where voters are allowed to acquire knowledge about the politician – except for his partisan affiliation.
nc2: The second group, in addition, receives the corruption news but still without co-partisan affiliation. This intends to serve as a benchmark for corruption sanctioning attitudes by measuring the effects of news exposure on approval without any source cues or elite arguments.
nc3: In the elite argument treatment group subjects will read in addition to the previous texts a short response/argument against the allegation from the involved actor, however, the politician’s partisanship will be still unknown.

B. Cue Block:
c1: The partisan control group where subjects read the same description, but with a co-partisan affiliation. This group intends to serve as the baseline measurement of the partisan approval by allowing for source cues.
c2: The second group which reads the description and receives the same corruption news but with partisan affiliations. This will measure the effects of news exposure conditional on co-partisanship.
c3: The final treatment group will read the description and receive a vignette featuring both the partisanship and the elite argument against the corruption allegation.

q9.value: The study uses full randomization for the vignette assignment. Random assignment to treatment groups is performed by the survey platform used for the data collection (LimeSurvey). Treatment groups are equally sized. The vignettes' order in the treatment groups are not randomized, they have a fixed order (description of the politician, corruption news, elite argument), however, treatment groups differ on how many vignettes subjects assigned to the specific group read (see experimental conditions above).

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value:
The data collection for the survey experiment was conducted as a part of the third-party, Hungarian social research institute's (TÁRKI) quarterly survey in late January, early February 2020. To ensure the timely completion of the research - tied to a funded research project, we decided to not delay the data collection to the 2nd quarter of 2020. This meant that data collection has been initiated before the pre-registration of the study.
The representative of the university research group received the raw data file on the 14 February 2020. The data file has not been observed by persons involved in the analysis of the data.

question.value: The survey is conducted by a reputable survey and research firm in Hungary (TÁRKI – Social Research Institute)  using a TAPI/CAPI technique for interviewing. The survey vendor randomly recruited the subjects based on a representative sampling frame of the Hungarian voter-aged population. The data collection runs until mid-February 2020.

q13.value: The sample consists of approximately 1.000 people. After the necessary selection of partisan voters - who can proceed to the experimental manipulation, we expect a sample size of around 850-950 people.

q14.value: The sample size was constrained by both funds and the size of the multi-investigator Omnibus study in which it was embedded.

question.value:
The study manipulates three variables, each is coded on a binary-level.
I. Corruption news exposure (the subject is exposed/not exposed)
II. Party cue availability (co-partisan affiliation is displayed/co-partisan affiliation is not displayed) 
III. Elite Argument (denial of accusation is shared with subjects/denial of accusation is not shared with respondents)

To measure the corruption sanctioning behavior of the subjects we use a two sets of outcome variables:

I. Mediation of the effects: Intermediary outcomes: Traits perception - traits are included in the bio (experience, accomplishment, competence) and the corruption perception as an assumed result of exposure to the news piece. Subjects will rate the mayor on a 1-5 scale along these dimensions.

II. Main effects: Main outcome: The question will ask the likelihood of voting for the politician featured in the vignettes if the subjects would live in the featured settlement and local election would be held the next day. Subjects will rate their likelihood of voting for the politician on a 1-5 scale.

For the intermediary outcomes where we measure the candidate trait rankings of the respondents, there are several distinct traits corresponding to different attributes, performance or accomplishment of the politician featured in the manipulation. As there is no specific theoretical expectations for the variation of the individual traits as a result of the treatment conditions, we average the awarded scores on these traits.

I. OLS Regression, main effect analysis:
First, we calculate the Sample Average Treatment Effect (SATE) in the different treatment conditions with the application of an OLS regression where we use the treatment groups as regression indicators. This will be carried out for the two experimental blocs separately (cue/no-cue block), therefore the reference group will always be the control group of the corresponding block. We regress the treatment variable on the main outcome, vote likelihood. The average effects of treatment conditions will be compared.

P(vote) = ß0 + ß1*experimental group indicator + Ɛ

II. OLS Regression, mechanism analysis:
Second, we are going to regress the treatment variable on the intermediary outcomes. In line with the assumed mechanisms: Once we regress on the corruption perception as the outcome, and once we create an index by averaging the trait outcome values.

P(corruption) = ß0 + ß1*experimental group indicator + Ɛ
P(traits) = ß0 + ß1*experimental group indicator + Ɛ

q21.value:
H1-H3: Directional hypotheses, a one-tailed test of significance with a critical p-value of p < .05. If the p-value is exceeded, we have no sufficient evidence against the null hypothesis.
H4: Null-effect hypothesis, a one-tailed test of significance with a critical p-value of p < .05. If p  > .05, then we have no sufficient evidence that the conditions fail to differ.

The multiple comparisons of experimental groups will be accounted for by Bonferroni-correction to adjust for the chance of statistically rare events accelerated by the testing of multiple hypotheses. The alpha level (.05) will be divided by the number of hypotheses (4) to gain a new alpha level for statistical significance of the findings (.05/4 = .0125).

q22.value: Respondents with No party preference/Don't know/Don't want to answer responses in the partisan preference pre-treatment question will be dropped from the experiment and excluded from the study. They will not be assigned to experimental conditions and will not receive vignette manipulations or outcome measurement questions.

q24.value: We will analyze the data separately for supporters of the government vs. opposition parties based on their answer to a pre-treatment question.

attributes.title: Voter Preferences in the Shadow of Foreign Aid

q1.value: Voter Preferences in the Shadow of Foreign Aid

q5.value: I want to thank the Center of Peace and Security Studies at UC San Diego for a small grant which made the survey experiment possible. I also want to thank Carnelian Co, my survey partners in Pakistan., Lastly, I would like to thank my advisor Professor Claire Adida for providing feedback on the initial design. I also want to thank Professor Megumi Naoi, during whose seminar I wrote the very first “thought paper” that later turned into this project., Professor Simeon Nichter provided valuable feedback and encouragement as I brought this project to fruition during his seminars., Lastly, I am grateful, as always, to my husband and daughter, whose incessant questions regarding my “results” and when I will be “done” helped me push through many late nights and early mornings.

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: Foreign aid may disrupt democracy if it serves as an unearned resource for politicians who no longer need to maintain the taxation-accountability linkage. However, in countries with low tax-to-GDP ratios and uncertain public goods delivery, voters may start holding politicians accountable for the successful delivery of foreign aid. I experimentally vary characteristics of public goods and candidates presented to respondents and estimate whether their linkage to foreign aid has an effect on voter preferences.

q16.value: 1. Voters are more likely to prefer public goods that receive funding from external sources to public goods funded by the domestic government. 2. Voters are more likely to prefer public goods that provide immediate cash to tangible public goods with long-run benefits. 3. Voters prefer candidates with previous work experience in international aid organizations to candidates who have worked in the domestic economy. 4. All else equal, voters prefer candidates with previous work experience in international organizations who also have degrees from an international institution, i.e., the effect of experience increases with education and vice versa. 5. Voters who are more knowledgeable about foreign aid are more likely to vote for a public good financed through foreign aid. 6. Voters who are more knowledgeable about foreign aid are more likely to vote for a political candidate who has previous work experience with international aid organizations.

q17.value: In order to develop a theory of voter preferences, I conducted a survey experiment amongst undergraduates in Pakistan, all of whom were of voting age at the time of Pakistan’s last General Elections in July 2018. I operationalize voter preferences by a choice-inducing behavioral measure, i.e., voting. After presenting respondents with two potential profiles (either of a candidate or of a public good), I ask which of the two they would want to vote for. By forcing respondents to choose between two options, I also introduce a cost in their decision-making process and increase the credibility of the measure. The choice-induced measure and structure of my instrument closely follows the immigration conjoint experiment carried out by Hainmuller and Hopkins (2015).

attributes.title: Parenting interventions for forcibly displaced families: A systematic review

q1.value: Parenting interventions for forcibly displaced families: A systematic review

q2.value: Sarah Gillespie, Jasmine Banegas, Akash Wasil, Athena C. Y. Chan, Joseph Maxwell, Neveen Ali Saleh-Darawshy, Scott Marsalis, Abigail Gewirtz

q3.value:
Rationale:
An estimated 70.8 million people globally have been displaced by war, persecution, natural disasters, and economic crises, and over half of these are children (United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, 2019). Forcibly displaced children are at elevated risk for mental illness; according to a recent systematic review, the overall prevalence in this population of post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) is 22.7%, depression is 13.8%, and anxiety disorders are 15.8% (Blackmore et al., 2019). Forced displacement impacts children directly—through exposure to traumatic events and deprivation of resources (Betancourt et al., 2012)—and also indirectly—through the impact of displacement on children’s caregiving environments (El-Khani et al., 2016). In immediate disaster or conflict settings, caregiver’s own physical or psychological distress, the loss of social support and community, living condition stressors, and children’s behavior changes can make it difficult for caregivers to support their child’s development (El-Khani et al., 2016). In resettlement contexts, caregivers may continue to face limited access to resources and social support, while also navigating differing parenting norms and family roles in a new context (Deng & Marlowe, 2013; Merry, Pelaez, & Edwards, 2017). Language and cultural differences may make parenting particularly challenging in the country of resettlement (Khawaja, Hebbani, Obijiofor, & Gallois, 2017).
 
Parenting interventions have the opportunity to strengthen caregivers’ abilities to buffer their children’s stress in the context of displacement and trauma exposure (Renzaho & Vignjevic, 2011). Many researchers have called for increased attention to parenting programs (El-Khani, Ulph, Peters, & Calam, n.d.; Fazel & Betancourt, 2018; Williams, 2012). To our knowledge, only one systematic review has assessed the availability and efficacy of family interventions for displaced populations (Slobodin & de Jong, 2015). This systematic review by Slobodin and de Jong—whose search was completed in 2013 and published in 2015— found only 6 studies that met their inclusion criteria; all six interventions reported a medium to large effect size on a range of outcomes. The majority of outcome measures assessed child improvement over the course of the family intervention (e.g., child PTSD, depression, and functional impairment), and a minority of studies assessed improvement in parenting (e.g., family problem solving, family hardiness). Since 2013, an additional 20 million individuals have been displaced, and increasing attention has been devoted to addressing the impact of forced displacement on children and families (UNHCR, 2019; Fazel & Betancourt, 2018). We will systematically review the characteristics and effectiveness of available parenting/caregiver interventions for forcibly displaced migrants. It is anticipated that the growing humanitarian crises will have stimulated intervention design and evaluation in recent years; a systematic review of progress and gaps in knowledge is thus timely and relevant. The results of this review can be used to inform development and dissemination of parenting interventions to families experiencing forced displacement.

 
Objectives:
The aim of this systematic review is to identify parenting programs for forcibly displaced persons and to evaluate the effectiveness of existing programs in both low and high income contexts. The proposed systematic review will answer the following questions:
1) For which forcibly displaced subpopulations do parenting programs exist (e.g., refugees, internally displaced persons, asylum seekers, and individuals displaced by natural disasters)? 
2) Are existing parenting programs targeted to diverse ethnic groups or tailored specifically to particular cultural groups (e.g., Somali, Syrian)?
3) What are the primary and secondary outcomes associated with parenting interventions for forcibly displaced caregivers? (E.g., parenting quality,  family conflict, children’s psychological health)
4) How many parenting programs have been developed for and evaluated with forcibly displaced persons living in low and middle income countries (LMICs) vs. in high income countries? Are there differences in program design and delivery across these contexts?
5) Do parenting programs for forcibly displaced persons show efficacy?

q4.value:
1) For which forcibly displaced subpopulations do parenting programs exist (e.g., refugees, internally displaced persons, asylum seekers, and individuals displaced by natural disasters)? 
Hypothesis: We do not have a specific hypotheses related to this exploratory research question.
2) Are existing parenting programs targeted to diverse ethnic groups or tailored specifically to particular cultural groups (e.g., Somali, Syrian)?
Hypothesis: We do not have a specific hypotheses related to this exploratory research question.
3) What are the primary and secondary outcomes associated with parenting interventions for forcibly displaced caregivers? (E.g., parenting quality,  family conflict, children’s psychological health)
Hypothesis: We do not have a specific hypotheses related to this exploratory research question.
4) How many parenting programs have been developed for and evaluated with forcibly displaced persons living in low and middle income countries (LMICs) relative to high income countries? 
Hypothesis: Most parenting programs (> 50%) will have been evaluated with forcibly displaced families living in high-income countries.
5) Do parenting programs for forcibly displaced persons show efficacy?
Hypothesis: The majority (> 50%) of parenting programs for forcibly displaced persons that have been evaluated relative to a comparison group will show efficacy for children and caregiver outcomes.

question.value:
Eligibility Criteria
1)    Study Designs: Given the ethical and logistical challenges of conducting randomized controlled trials (RCTs) in the context of humanitarian crises, we will include a broad range of study designs on parenting programs for forcibly displaced persons: RCTs, quasi-experimental designs, waitlist control, descriptive studies, and pilot evaluations. Study protocols and program descriptions will also be included in order to describe the availability of programs whose efficacy is not yet known.
2)    Participants: The United Nations recognizes that over 70.8 million individuals are forcibly displaced; our review aims to identify programs that might assist those who are experiencing forced displacement due to diverse causes. We will, therefore, include studies that target parents and caregivers who have experienced forced displacement due to war, conflict, persecution, or natural disaster. Participants in included studies 1) must be caring for a child or adolescent and 2) must have themselves have a history of forced displacement. Participants can be living in low and middle income countries (LMICs) or be resettled in high-income countries.
3)    Interventions: We will include preventive programs or treatments designed to improve the caregiving abilities of forcibly displaced parents and caregivers.

Information sources:
We will search online databases for original articles, chapters, dissertations, and systematic reviews. Databases to be searched include: PsycInfo (Ovid), Medline (Ovid), CINAHL (Proquest), Academic Search Premier (EBSCOhost), Scopus, PTSDpubs (Proquest), Dissertations & Theses (Proquest), Campbell Collaboration, Cochrane Library, and Social Care Online. The reference list of included studies will be scanned to ensure literature saturation. When published abstracts are insufficient, we will reach out to the first author to solicit additional data. 

Search Strategy:  
Studies in English, Chinese, Hebrew, Arabic, and Spanish will be included, as these are spoken by team members and resources limit our ability for additional translation. We will not limit studies by date nor geography. The specific search strategies for each database will be designed by the research team in collaboration with a Social Sciences Librarian with expertise in systematic review searching. The draft search strategy for PsycInfo is included as Appendix 1. Additional studies will be identified by searching the citation lists of included articles and by searching additional articles that have cited included studies. This will ensure literature saturation.
 
Study Records
Literature search results will be imported into Covidence, an Internet based software program that supports deduplication, collaboration among reviewers during the screening process, and the creation of a PRISMA flow diagram upon screening completion. Automatic and manual de-duplication will be conducted in Covidence. It is possible that studies will be published in more than one location, such as a dissertation that is later published in a peer reviewed journal. When duplicates exist, peer-reviewed articles will be retained and other versions deleted. All such decisions will be recorded and reported.
 
All reviewers will be trained on the Covidence software by a librarian with experience in this software. The screening criteria will be piloted by having all reviewers screen a subset of abstracts; this process will be used to refine the criteria and establish consensus among reviewers. Individual reviewers will then code abstracts and full text articles; Covidence will record their decisions allowing reliability to be calculated.

Selection process.
All screeners participated in the development of the review aims and inclusion/exclusion criteria; they have equal familiarity with the study goals and screening process. Reviewers will independently apply our inclusion criteria to the titles and abstracts included in the search results. Each reviewer will be randomly assigned to screen particular abstracts. Each abstract will be reviewed by at least two reviewers; disagreements will be recorded and resolved by group discussion. Rater agreement will be calculated. Reviewers will then screen full text articles and seek information from study authors if further information is needed in order to determine whether a study meets the inclusion criteria. Disagreements will be recorded and resolved through discussion. All exclusions during abstract and full text screening will be recorded. Reviewers will have access to all publication information during screening, including journal titles and study authors and institutions.

question.value:
Data Collection Process.
Data will be extracted from included articles using a standardized form. Piloting of data extraction forms will be conducted prior to the formal process in order to establish consensus among team members. Two reviewers will extract all data and check for agreement; we will contact study authors a maximum of three times when further information is needed. Disagreements on any data will be resolved through discussion with a third member of the team.
 
Data items.
The standardized data extraction form will include variables of interest: year of publication, study location/language, intervention characteristics, sample size, sample characteristics (e.g., migration status, country of origin, caregiver role, etc), study design, primary and secondary outcome measures, and follow up duration. Intervention characteristics will include duration of contact with parents (e.g., three 1-hour sessions over one month), inclusion of children in the intervention, credentials and training of program facilitators, and mode of delivery (e.g., face-to-face, group format, self-paced videotapes).
 
Risk of bias in individual studies.
A standardized checklist developed by (Chacón-Moscoso, Sanduvete-Chaves, & Sánchez-Martín (2016) will be applied by reviewers to code the methodological quality and risk of bias in the included studies. Reviewers will calibrate their ratings on a sample of articles, and then will independently rate half of the studies using the appropriate tool. This tool assesses the risk for selection, performance, detection, attrition, reporting, and other biases. All assessments will be done at effect size level, namely, the outcome level. We will not exclude studies based on the risk of bias; instead, we will examine the impact of the risk of bias on study results. Meetings will be held to resolve disagreements.

Data synthesis. The planned review will include a systematic narrative synthesis of study designs, intervention characteristics (e.g., length, delivery mechanism), targeted populations, location of implementation (e.g., high-income countries or low- and middle-income countries), and primary/secondary outcomes. For evaluating the intervention effect in designs using comparison groups, Cohen’s d will be calculated for each outcome.

Confidence in the cumulative evidence will be assessed according to (1) the results of our assessment of bias in the published literature and (2) the type of study design and any available replication studies that examine the efficacy of each treatment. Based on these assessments, Chambless & Hollon's (1998) criteria for Empirically Supported Psychological Therapies will be applied to grade treatments as “possibly efficacious,” “efficacious,” and “efficacious and specific.” These criteria draw on the foundations provided by the Division 12 (Clinical Psychology) Task Force on Promotion and Dissemination of Psychological Procedures (1995) and the American Psychological Association (APA) Task Force on Psychological Intervention Guidelines (1995), and have been widely accepted as a framework for assessing the quality and quantity of evidence supporting a treatment’s efficacy.

q21.value: For studies that test the parenting program relative to a comparison group, Cohen’s d will be calculated to describe group differences in outcome variables. Standard cut-points will be used to evaluate effect sizes: a small effect size = 0.2;  medium effect size = 0.5; and a large effect size > 0.8.

registration_responses.q1: Parenting interventions for forcibly displaced families: A systematic review
registration_responses.q2: Sarah Gillespie, Jasmine Banegas, Akash Wasil, Athena C. Y. Chan, Joseph Maxwell, Neveen Ali Saleh-Darawshy, Scott Marsalis, Abigail Gewirtz
registration_responses.q3:
Rationale:
An estimated 70.8 million people globally have been displaced by war, persecution, natural disasters, and economic crises, and over half of these are children (United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, 2019). Forcibly displaced children are at elevated risk for mental illness; according to a recent systematic review, the overall prevalence in this population of post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) is 22.7%, depression is 13.8%, and anxiety disorders are 15.8% (Blackmore et al., 2019). Forced displacement impacts children directly—through exposure to traumatic events and deprivation of resources (Betancourt et al., 2012)—and also indirectly—through the impact of displacement on children’s caregiving environments (El-Khani et al., 2016). In immediate disaster or conflict settings, caregiver’s own physical or psychological distress, the loss of social support and community, living condition stressors, and children’s behavior changes can make it difficult for caregivers to support their child’s development (El-Khani et al., 2016). In resettlement contexts, caregivers may continue to face limited access to resources and social support, while also navigating differing parenting norms and family roles in a new context (Deng & Marlowe, 2013; Merry, Pelaez, & Edwards, 2017). Language and cultural differences may make parenting particularly challenging in the country of resettlement (Khawaja, Hebbani, Obijiofor, & Gallois, 2017).
 
Parenting interventions have the opportunity to strengthen caregivers’ abilities to buffer their children’s stress in the context of displacement and trauma exposure (Renzaho & Vignjevic, 2011). Many researchers have called for increased attention to parenting programs (El-Khani, Ulph, Peters, & Calam, n.d.; Fazel & Betancourt, 2018; Williams, 2012). To our knowledge, only one systematic review has assessed the availability and efficacy of family interventions for displaced populations (Slobodin & de Jong, 2015). This systematic review by Slobodin and de Jong—whose search was completed in 2013 and published in 2015— found only 6 studies that met their inclusion criteria; all six interventions reported a medium to large effect size on a range of outcomes. The majority of outcome measures assessed child improvement over the course of the family intervention (e.g., child PTSD, depression, and functional impairment), and a minority of studies assessed improvement in parenting (e.g., family problem solving, family hardiness). Since 2013, an additional 20 million individuals have been displaced, and increasing attention has been devoted to addressing the impact of forced displacement on children and families (UNHCR, 2019; Fazel & Betancourt, 2018). We will systematically review the characteristics and effectiveness of available parenting/caregiver interventions for forcibly displaced migrants. It is anticipated that the growing humanitarian crises will have stimulated intervention design and evaluation in recent years; a systematic review of progress and gaps in knowledge is thus timely and relevant. The results of this review can be used to inform development and dissemination of parenting interventions to families experiencing forced displacement.

 
Objectives:
The aim of this systematic review is to identify parenting programs for forcibly displaced persons and to evaluate the effectiveness of existing programs in both low and high income contexts. The proposed systematic review will answer the following questions:
1) For which forcibly displaced subpopulations do parenting programs exist (e.g., refugees, internally displaced persons, asylum seekers, and individuals displaced by natural disasters)? 
2) Are existing parenting programs targeted to diverse ethnic groups or tailored specifically to particular cultural groups (e.g., Somali, Syrian)?
3) What are the primary and secondary outcomes associated with parenting interventions for forcibly displaced caregivers? (E.g., parenting quality,  family conflict, children’s psychological health)
4) How many parenting programs have been developed for and evaluated with forcibly displaced persons living in low and middle income countries (LMICs) vs. in high income countries? Are there differences in program design and delivery across these contexts?
5) Do parenting programs for forcibly displaced persons show efficacy?
registration_responses.q4:

Hypothesis: We do not have a specific hypotheses related to this exploratory research question.

Hypothesis: We do not have a specific hypotheses related to this exploratory research question.
3) What are the primary and secondary outcomes associated with parenting interventions for forcibly displaced caregivers? (E.g., parenting quality,  family conflict, children’s psychological health)
Hypothesis: We do not have a specific hypotheses related to this exploratory research question.
4) How many parenting programs have been developed for and evaluated with forcibly displaced persons living in low and middle income countries (LMICs) relative to high income countries? 
Hypothesis: Most parenting programs (> 50%) will have been evaluated with forcibly displaced families living in high-income countries.
5) Do parenting programs for forcibly displaced persons show efficacy?
Hypothesis: The majority (> 50%) of parenting programs for forcibly displaced persons that have been evaluated relative to a comparison group will show efficacy for children and caregiver outcomes.

attributes.title: The role of augmented feedback in the learning and performance of gross motor skills: a systematic review

summary.value:
1.	Review title: The role of augmented feedback in the learning and performance of gross motor skills: a systematic review

2.	Original language title: The role of augmented feedback in the performance of gross motor skills: a systematic review

3.	Stage of review at time of this submission: The review has not yet started.	
	                                                                                                           Started	Completed
        Review stage 	                                                                                 ✔                     ✖
        Preliminary searches 	                                                       	                 ✔	                 ✖
        Piloting of the study selection process	                                         ✖	                 ✖
        Formal screening of search results against eligibility criteria	 ✖	                 ✖
        Data extraction	                                                                                 ✖	                 ✖
        Risk of bias (quality) assessment 		                                         ✖	                 ✖
        Data analysis	                                                                                 ✖	                 ✖

4.	Named contact: Emma Petancevski

5.	Named contact email: Emma.Petancevski@student.uts.edu.au 

6.	Named contact address: UTS Moore Park precinct. Level 3, Corner of Moore Park Rd and Driver Avenue. Moore Park, NSW 2021

7.	Named contact phone number: 95145207

8.	Organisational affiliation of the review: University of Technology Sydney 

9.	Review team members and their organisational affiliations:
Emma Petancevski, Faculty of Health, University of Technology Sydney
Professor Franco M Impellizzeri, Faculty of Health, University of Technology Sydney
Dr Job Fransen, Faculty of Health, University of Technology Sydney
Joshua Inns, Faculty of Health, University of Technology Sydney

10.	Funding sources/sponsors: None

11.	Conflicts of interest: The authors have no conflicts to declare

12.	Collaborators: None to declare

13.	Review question: What is the impact of augmented feedback on the learning and performance of gross motor skills in adults?

14.	Searches:  The following electronic bibliographic databases will be searched: Pubmed, Web of Science and PsycINFO.  Additionally, a manual search of bibliographies. 

Search terms: 
Intervention: “augmented feedback” OR “extrinsic feedback” OR “external feedback” OR “verbal feedback” OR “video feedback” OR “biofeedback” OR “videotape feedback” OR “knowledge of results” OR “knowledge of performance” 
Outcome: skill OR learning OR performance OR control AND motor 

Eligibility: Studies using augmented feedback to learn or improve the performance of a gross motor skill

Inclusion Criteria: 
•	Research design: Pre-Post Test Randomised Control Trials 
•	All languages included 
•	No restriction on publication year

Excluded: None

Data extracted: Authors, year of publication, number of participants, population characteristics (age, gender, training status), gross motor skill/sport learnt or performed, augmented feedback intervention used, duration of the intervention, data pre- and post-intervention 

15.	Condition or domain being studied: Gross motor skills and sports requiring gross muscle movement

16.	Participants/population: 

Inclusion: Adults >18 years, males and females, any sport or any gross motor skill 
Exclusion: Children or elderly people, clinical populations and rehabilitation setting

17.	Intervention(s), exposure(s): Augmented feedback, and all synonymous terms, i.e. extrinsic feedback, video feedback, verbal feedback, knowledge of results etc. 

18.	Comparator(s)/control: No restriction 

19.	Types of study to be included:

Inclusion criteria: 
•	Research designs: Pre-Post Test Randomised Control Trials
•	Augmented feedback measures used in motor learning or motor performance in gross motor skills and sports

Exclusion criteria:
•	Reviews (any kind)
•	Meta-analysis

20.	Context: Studies in sport and exercise settings. Athletes ranging from recreational to professional level.

21.	Main outcome(s): The effectiveness of different types of augmented feedback interventions across different gross motor skills

22.	Additional outcome(s): Not applicable. 

23.	Data extraction (selection and coding): The title and abstracts of studies retrieved using the search strategy will be screened by two of the review authors to identify studies that potentially meet the inclusion criteria outlined above.  The full text of the short-listed studies will be retrieved and independently assessed by two review authors for eligibility.  An additional reviewer will be utilised should any disagreement arise over eligibility of particular studies.  The authors will resolve any disagreement through discussion. 

The following data will be retrieved from each eligible study:
•	Type of augmented feedback intervention used
•	Gross motor skill learnt/performed 
•	Data pre- and post-intervention 
•	Effect size 

24.	Risk of bias (quality) assessment: The risk of bias will be assessed using the Cochrane Risk of Bias Tool for randomised control trials (Higgins et al. 2011).

25.	Strategy for data synthesis: Tables will be used to summarise the findings of the included studies.  The narrative synthesis will explore the findings within and between the included studies. 

26.	Analysis of subgroups or subsets: Novices vs experts, younger vs older adults, team vs individual sport

27.	Type and method of review: Systematic review

28.	Language: All

29.	Country: Australia

30.	Dissemination plans: The review will be submitted to a leading journal in the field of Sports science. 

31.	Keywords: Systematic review; augmented feedback; motor learning; motor performance; gross motor skills 

32.	Details of any existing review of the same topic by the same authors: None

33.	Current review status: Review - ongoing

1.	Review title: The role of augmented feedback in the learning and performance of gross motor skills: a systematic review

2.	Original language title: The role of augmented feedback in the performance of gross motor skills: a systematic review

3.	Stage of review at time of this submission: The review has not yet started.

        Review stage 	                                                                                 ✔                     ✖

        Data extraction	                                                                                 ✖	                 ✖
        Risk of bias (quality) assessment 		                                         ✖	                 ✖
        Data analysis	                                                                                 ✖	                 ✖

4.	Named contact: Emma Petancevski

5.	Named contact email: Emma.Petancevski@student.uts.edu.au 

6.	Named contact address: UTS Moore Park precinct. Level 3, Corner of Moore Park Rd and Driver Avenue. Moore Park, NSW 2021

7.	Named contact phone number: 95145207

8.	Organisational affiliation of the review: University of Technology Sydney 

9.	Review team members and their organisational affiliations:
Emma Petancevski, Faculty of Health, University of Technology Sydney
Professor Franco M Impellizzeri, Faculty of Health, University of Technology Sydney
Dr Job Fransen, Faculty of Health, University of Technology Sydney
Joshua Inns, Faculty of Health, University of Technology Sydney

10.	Funding sources/sponsors: None

11.	Conflicts of interest: The authors have no conflicts to declare

12.	Collaborators: None to declare

13.	Review question: What is the impact of augmented feedback on the learning and performance of gross motor skills in adults?

14.	Searches:  The following electronic bibliographic databases will be searched: Pubmed, Web of Science and PsycINFO.  Additionally, a manual search of bibliographies. 

Search terms: 
Intervention: “augmented feedback” OR “extrinsic feedback” OR “external feedback” OR “verbal feedback” OR “video feedback” OR “biofeedback” OR “videotape feedback” OR “knowledge of results” OR “knowledge of performance” 
Outcome: skill OR learning OR performance OR control AND motor 

Eligibility: Studies using augmented feedback to learn or improve the performance of a gross motor skill

Inclusion Criteria: 
•	Research design: Pre-Post Test Randomised Control Trials 
•	All languages included 
•	No restriction on publication year

Excluded: None

Data extracted: Authors, year of publication, number of participants, population characteristics (age, gender, training status), gross motor skill/sport learnt or performed, augmented feedback intervention used, duration of the intervention, data pre- and post-intervention 

15.	Condition or domain being studied: Gross motor skills and sports requiring gross muscle movement

16.	Participants/population: 

Inclusion: Adults >18 years, males and females, any sport or any gross motor skill 
Exclusion: Children or elderly people, clinical populations and rehabilitation setting

17.	Intervention(s), exposure(s): Augmented feedback, and all synonymous terms, i.e. extrinsic feedback, video feedback, verbal feedback, knowledge of results etc. 

18.	Comparator(s)/control: No restriction 

19.	Types of study to be included:

Inclusion criteria: 
•	Research designs: Pre-Post Test Randomised Control Trials
•	Augmented feedback measures used in motor learning or motor performance in gross motor skills and sports

Exclusion criteria:
•	Reviews (any kind)
•	Meta-analysis

20.	Context: Studies in sport and exercise settings. Athletes ranging from recreational to professional level.

21.	Main outcome(s): The effectiveness of different types of augmented feedback interventions across different gross motor skills

22.	Additional outcome(s): Not applicable. 

23.	Data extraction (selection and coding): The title and abstracts of studies retrieved using the search strategy will be screened by two of the review authors to identify studies that potentially meet the inclusion criteria outlined above.  The full text of the short-listed studies will be retrieved and independently assessed by two review authors for eligibility.  An additional reviewer will be utilised should any disagreement arise over eligibility of particular studies.  The authors will resolve any disagreement through discussion. 

The following data will be retrieved from each eligible study:
•	Type of augmented feedback intervention used
•	Gross motor skill learnt/performed 
•	Data pre- and post-intervention 
•	Effect size 

24.	Risk of bias (quality) assessment: The risk of bias will be assessed using the Cochrane Risk of Bias Tool for randomised control trials (Higgins et al. 2011).

25.	Strategy for data synthesis: Tables will be used to summarise the findings of the included studies.  The narrative synthesis will explore the findings within and between the included studies. 

26.	Analysis of subgroups or subsets: Novices vs experts, younger vs older adults, team vs individual sport

27.	Type and method of review: Systematic review

28.	Language: All

29.	Country: Australia

30.	Dissemination plans: The review will be submitted to a leading journal in the field of Sports science. 

31.	Keywords: Systematic review; augmented feedback; motor learning; motor performance; gross motor skills

attributes.title: Same same OR Different?
attributes.description:
With this project, I aim to investigate combinations of characteristics within people.


While trying to determine the universal building blocks of personality, it seems that researchers have focused on similarities rather than differences; In both regards: Similarities between people, as well as between personality characteristics. Accumulating research is now challenging prominent conceptualizations of personality and with it the method of aggregation. By aggregating item responses into sum scores and individuals into groups, relevant differences between them might have been overlooked. Our goal is to offer new levels of explanation to allow the integration of findings.
To this end, we will cluster people by their item-response-patterns. We will investigate the heterogeneity of these clusters, and assess if similar levels (i.e. sums scores) on the five domains of the five factor model can reduce heterogeneity by accounting for similarities between item-response-patterns. Next to this confirmatory part, we aim to largely explore the combinations of characteristics within people by describing the possible cluster solutions. We will split our sample into three samples to be able to test any findings the result from exploration.

Personality characteristics will be operationalized as the 263 unique items (of the full 300 version) of the IPIP-NEO, also called personality "nuances". René Mõttus research line has examined these nuances intensively and found, among other features, rank-order stability, cross-rater agreement, heritability. He has suggests them to be included in the personality trait hierarchy.

q1.value: Lea Rahel Dorothee Westphal, René Mõttus, Anna Lichtwarck-Aschoff, Fred Hasselman

q2.value:
R1 (confirmatory):
Do item-response-patterns (i.e. cluster belonging) vary systematically as a function of domain scores? That is, high scores tend to go with some item-profile, medium scores with another and lower scores with yet another. Does accounting for domain level reduce heterogeneity among item-response-patterns (i.e. cluster belonging)?
R2 (exploratory):
How do the clusters of item-response-patterns differ/ are similar to each other, besides potentially systematic differences in their mean domain scores? Are some clusters more common within some domains than others? What theoretical explanation could explain these differences?

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
(same as "analysis plan", as our data is already collected)
To investigate both research questions we will use existing, openly accessible data (see Johnson, 2014, or https://osf.io/tbmh514), that was anonymously collected online. Participants completed the 300-item personality questionnaire (IPIP-NEO; Goldberg, 1999) based on International Personality Item Pool reproducing the structure of the five factor model as the NEO-PI does. 

Wrangling
We will exclude participants that do not come from English speaking countries. We will also delete each one item that has a duplicate (pair) within the item pool, based on which of the two has the higher entropy. 
We will split our sample into three samples so that we can test any findings from one sample on another sample (by the means of prediction).

Analysis
We will use hierarchical clustering (agglomerative and/or divisive) to cluster people ('s item-response-patterns). 

We will explore (describe):
Which items (levels) go together?
Which items (levels) are most/ least constant/ variable (the most variable ones will not determine group membership) within the clusters?

q8.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q9.value: I have not run any analyses yet. We will split the data in 3 samples so that we can test our results (by means of prediction).

q20.value:
Wrangling
We will exclude participants that do not come from English speaking countries to reduce language-bias (understanding of the items which are written in English). 
We will also delete each one item that has a duplicate (pair) within the item pool, based on which of the two has the higher entropy. This way we can interpret item-response-patterns representing unique characteristics, and avoid distortion of the clusters through differences in the participants' answers on duplicates.

q21.value: We will delete all cases including missing data.

q22.value:
Analysis
We will use hierarchical clustering (agglomerative and/or divisive) to cluster people ('s item-response-patterns). 
Our analysis will be largely exploratory. However, we will split our sample into three samples so that we can test any findings from one sample on another sample (by the means of prediction).

attributes.title: Determinants of Support for Vigilantism in Guatemala

q2.value:
In this project we describe two distinct "logics" of vigilante justice and outline expectations both for AMCEs from the conjoint experiment as well as for observational data from the same survey. 

LOGIC 1 
If the aim of vigilante justice is behavior control ("Behavioral Control Logic"), then:

Using conjoint attributes: 

1) Type of Crime: Type of crime does not impact the likelihood of a criminal being preferred for vigilante punishment.
2) Victim Gender: Victim gender does not impact the likelihood of a criminal being preferred for vigilante punishment.
3) Perpetrator Affiliation: Relative to other perpetrators, a police affiliation increases the likelihood of a criminal being preferred for vigilante punishment.  
4) Perpetrator Gender: Perpetrator gender does not impact the likelihood of a criminal being preferred for vigilante punishment.
5) Perpetrator Relationship: Perpetrator relationship to the respondent does not impact the likelihood of a criminal being preferred for vigilante punishment.  

Using other survey data:

6) State Presence: Weak state capacity is positively correlated with support for vigilantism.  
7) Victimization: Personal experience with crime victimization does not correlate with increased support for vigilantism
8) Vigilantism-Severity Correlation: Preferring a criminal for vigilante punishment is uncorrelated with preferring a criminal for severe punishment. 

LOGIC 2
If the aim of vigilante justice is retribution/revenge ("Retributive Justice Logic"), then:

Using conjoint attributes: 

1) Type of Crime: The more severe the crime is, the greater the likelihood of a criminal being preferred for vigilante punishment. 
2) Victim Gender: Relative to committing a crime against a man, committing a crime against a woman increases the likelihood of a criminal being preferred for vigilante punishment.
3) Perpetrator Affiliation 1: Relative to regular citizens, a police affiliation increases the likelihood of a criminal being preferred for vigilante punishment. 
4) Perpetrator Affiliation 2: Relative to regular citizens, a gang affiliation increases the likelihood of a criminal being preferred for vigilante punishment. 
5) Perpetrator Gender: Relative to being a woman, being a man increases the likelihood of a criminal being preferred for vigilante punishment.
6) Perpetrator Relationship: Being closer the respondent decreases the likelihood of a criminal being preferred for vigilante punishment. 

Using other survey data: 

7) State Presence: Local state capacity is uncorrelated with support for vigilantism. 
8) Victimization: Personal experience with crime victimization is positively correlated with support for vigilantism 
9) Vigilantism-Severity Correlation: Preferring a criminal for vigilante punishment is correlated with preferring a criminal for severe punishment.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Although the survey covers a wide range of topics, the key element for this project is a forced choice conjoint experiment in which respondents are presented with information regarding randomized attributes of two hypothetical crimes. Given the length of the survey, the conjoint module was presented to a randomly selected half of all respondents. 

The prompt preceding the conjoint is as follows: 

    "Occasionally there are crimes that occur within communities. In some cases, people think it is better to let the police investigate the crime and punish the perpetrator. In other cases, people think that the community should take matters into their own hands. Consider the following scenarios and tell me in which case you think it would be better for the community to take matters into their own hands. Even if you are not completely sure, choose one of the cases."

Following the presentation of the two hypothetical crimes, respondents are asked, "of the two scenarios, in which case do you think it would be better for someone in the community rather than the police to punish the perpetrator directly?" They are then asked, "And of the two scenarios, which case do you think should be punished more severely?" The attributes and levels are included in the conjoint are attached in the pre-analysis plan.

q7.value: A random half of all survey respondents answered the conjoint experiment questions. Within the conjoint, all attributes are randomized independently of one another. The attribute order was not randomized.

q8.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q9.value: The data for this study has been kept in a Dropbox folder. However, the parts of the survey pertaining to the conjoint experiment have not yet been cleaned or analyzed by either author.

question.value:
The data for this project comes from an endline survey conducted in Guatemala which evaluated the success of the Guatemala MPP Project. This program, funded by the United States Department of State's Bureau of International Narcotics and Law Enforcement and implemented by RTI International, ran from June 2016 through June 2019. It was designed to strengthen collaboration between the Guatemalan National Civil Police and municipal governments through the creation of model police precincts across the country. Although the data has already been collected, we have not yet examined it at the time of the posting of this Pre-Analysis Plan.  

The endline survey was conducted in July through September of 2019, and there were over 18,700 respondents. The population of interest consisted of all adults over the age of 18 living in both the urban and rural areas of 65 Guatemalan municipalities. There were two stages of respondent selection. Firstly, the primary sampling unit was the "nuclear populated place;" these units are equivalent to census tracts in the United States. Populated places were chosen with a probability equal to the number of citizens in the populated nucleus divided by the number of citizens in the municipality. The secondary sampling units were dwellings within selected populated places; these dwellings were chosen through a systematic walk. The final unit of sampling is the person of legal age that inhabits the dwelling. If there were multiple eligible adults in the dwelling, the one with the most recent birthday is sampled. The survey was programmed in SurveyCTO, a platform based upon Open Data Kit (ODK). Information from the in-person interviews was recorded on tablets. In addition to Spanish, surveys were conducted in Poqomchi', Ixil, and Q'ekchi.

q12.value: The sample size was determined by programmatic and funding limits. Because the survey is an endline survey, its principal substantive goal is to evaluate a program. Therefore, the survey was fielded in locations relevant for the model policing program.

question.value: See the "Design Plan" section and the attached document. In short, the conjoint attributes are manipulated.

1) [Conjoint] Vig 1: Of the two scenarios, in which case do you think it would be better for someone in the community rather than the police to punish the perpetrator directly?"
2) [Conjoint] Vig 2: And of the two scenarios, which case do you think should be punished more severely?
3) Vig 3: Suppose that a man kills someone who had sexually assaulted his daughter. Would you approve that he kill the perpetrator, would you approve but understand his position, or would you not approve nor understand his position?
4) Vic. 1 - Vic. 11: questions about household experiences with crime
5) VC.1A, CV.2, POL.10, REP.1A, TR1-9: questions concerning local state capacity
6) Control and exploratory variables
For 4) and 5) above, we will explore correlations among the variables and consider the extent of nonresponse to potentially create indices using principal component analysis.
We will estimate AMCEs, common in the analysis of conjoint experiments. We will use the "cregg" package in R.

q21.value: We will look at patterns of missingness in the data. Assuming low missingness in the experiment, we will simply drop missing observations. If missigness appears more widespread, we will consider imputing missing data using Amelia or MICE.

q22.value: We expect that preferences for community justice will vary across communities depending on the level of police presence, civil war exposure, and extent to which the population is indigenous. Therefore, we will consider either interacting the conjoint attributes with relevant contextual variables (quality of policing, amount of crime, presence of lynchings, amount of civil war violence, presence of civil war patrols, percent of respondents identifying as indigenous or speaking non-Spanish language). This information will either from survey data itself or from municipal data. We may also subset the conjoint results on the basis of these variables.
